2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e6e3a0b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/5555x3118+0+294/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F79%2Fce%2F62b0ca07476699c58c0c46d5dbbc%2Fbroadviewfaithleaders-111525-09.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>El reverendo Michael Woolf fue detenido en noviembre pasado durante una protesta cerca de la instalación de ICE en el suburbio oeste de Broadview.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Varias personas resultaron heridas durante el enfrentamiento ese día, incluyendo cuatro policías.</p><p>La Policía Estatal de Illinois, el Sheriff del Condado de Cook y la Policía de Broadview lanzaron un comando unificado a principios de octubre para manejar el control de multitudes en las casi diarias manifestaciones frente a la instalación de inmigración.</p><p>Las agencias de aplicación de la ley locales arrestaron al menos a 113 personas frente a la instalación entre principios de octubre y finales de noviembre.</p><p>Los manifestantes han acusado a las agencias locales de violar la Ley TRUST, que prohíbe a las fuerzas del orden de Illinois trabajar con agentes federales en la aplicación de las leyes de inmigración.</p><p>La mayoría de esos casos de arresto aún están pendientes ante la Corte del Condado de Cook.</p><p>También hubo al menos 13 personas arrestadas por agentes federales mientras protestaban frente a la instalación de Broadview el otoño pasado. Seis ya han tenido sus casos desestimados.</p><p>Los otros siete, incluido el grupo conocido como los “Broadview Six”, aún tienen casos pendientes. Los “Broadview Six” irán a juicio en mayo.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>

entries.title: Seeding the IHSA Class 4A sectionals
entries.summary: <p>By the end of this week the IHSA state basketball tournament brackets will be set. The road to Champaign will be laid out.</p><p>But first comes the seeding process as coaches from across the state will seed the sectionals this week.</p><p>There is a lot that should go into seeding a sectional. The win total does matter. The sparkling record, however, can sometimes be deceiving. Who those wins came against — the number of quality wins a team has compiled — should be taken into account.</p><p>The other factors to consider: head-to-head results, how a team is currently playing and the old fashioned look test.</p><p>The annual City/Suburban Hoops Report seeding forecast is here for Class 4A. Here are the top eight seeds for each Class 4A sectional across the Chicago area, including the reasons and defense of those seeds.</p><h3>Bartlett Sectional</h3><p>1. Glenbard East (24-3)<br>2. York (24-4)<br>3. Batavia (18-8)<br>4. Glenbard North (19-6)<br>5. Wheaton-Warrenville South (17-9)<br>6. Wheaton North (15-9)<br>7. Leyden (19-7)<br>8. Glenbard West (10-14)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> Glenbard East did suffer an upset loss to Riverside-Brookfield last week, but it’s certainly done enough to warrant the No. 1 seed.</p><p>York has been one of the surprise teams of the year and has won 12 of its last 13. Despite a one-point loss to Batavia back in December, York still gets the slight edge as the second seed due to its full body of work.</p><p>The résumé for both York and Batavia are similar, but York’s six additional wins must count for something. And Batavia’s eight losses over the course of two-plus months isn’t just in a vacuum.</p><p>But if we’re talking about the hottest team that’s playing the best basketball? It’s Batavia. The Bulldogs are 13-1 since holiday tournament time and are 15-3 since their 3-5 start to the season. It’s been a complete and impressive turnaround.</p><p>The red-hot Bulldogs also beat Glenbard North in January after falling to them twice earlier in the season.</p><p>Glenbard North lost to Wheaton South in December but did win the most recent matchup. That nudges them up to the No. 4 seed.</p><p>Wheaton South has beaten Wheaton North twice this season — by a combined three points — to secure the fifth seed and a likely third matchup with Glenbard North in the regional championship.</p><p>Leyden is the outlier. There is the solid win total, but it has only beaten two teams, Mather and Morton, with a winning record. Glenbard West’s record falls short, but the schedule the Hilltoppers have faced is rock solid.</p><h3>Mount Carmel Sectional</h3><p>1. Curie (22-1)<br>2. St. Ignatius (24-4)<br>3. Young (20-6)<br>4. Mount Carmel (16-10)<br>5. St. Laurence (21-6)<br>6. Riverside-Brookfield (20-6)<br>7. Lyons (18-6)<br>8. Kenwood (15-6)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> In a sectional where there are 13 teams with winning records and another three hovering right at the .500 mark, this is the most difficult sectional to seed. Well, not at the top. But it gets tough immediately after the top two seeds are placed.</p><p>Curie and St. Ignatius have both done their work to earn those top two seeds.</p><p>Young, which lost to St. Ignatius by just one point early in the season, has a strong schedule and hot streak — the Dolphins have won 14 of their last 15 — to help nab the three seed.</p><p>Mount Carmel and St. Laurence have scuffled of late while facing the grueling part of their schedules. St. Laurence has the win total but is just 2-5 (through Monday) in the Catholic League and lacks the marquee wins. Mount Carmel has beaten Loyola, Lincoln Park and owns an overtime win over St. Laurence a few weeks ago.</p><p>Riverside-Brookfield has quietly put together a strong second half of the season. The Bulldogs just lost their first game since Christmas this past weekend, falling to Oak Lawn, and have beaten Lyons and a ranked Glenbard East in the second half of the season.</p><p>The No. 8 and No. 9 seeds will be filled by either Kenwood, Oak Lawn, Simeon or Perspectives-Leadership.</p><p>In a bizarre twist, Simeon is unranked and quickly falls out of the conversation of being a top eight seed. The Wolverines don’t have a single statement win on the season. The best win to-date is a 56-55 victory over Class 2A Peoria Manual (15-8). That takes them out of the conversation.</p><p>Oak Lawn has 22 wins and did get a quality win over Riverside-Brookfield over the weekend. But it hasn’t faced the schedule of others in this sectional, playing just one ranked team all season, losing to Mount Carmel.</p><p>Kenwood was just blasted by Hillcrest over the weekend, but it did beat Rich, Lincoln Park, Hyde Park and it took care of Perspectives-Leadership. They’ve also played New Trier, Peoria Richwoods and Loyola. That schedule earns them the No. 8 seed, edging out Oak Lawn, who would settle in at No. 9, followed by nine-loss Perspectives-Leadership at 10.</p><p>You are looking at some dangerous regional semifinal games for some higher seeded teams with the likes of Perspectives-Leadership and Simeon falling to 10 and 11.</p><h3>Joliet West Sectional</h3><p>1. Homewood-Flossmoor (22-3)<br>2. Marist (24-4)<br>3. Lockport (22-4)<br>4. Brother Rice (19-9)<br>5. Lincoln-Way Central (17-8)<br>6. Joliet West (18-8)<br>7. Thornwood (18-9)<br>8. Rich (14-12)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> The top three seeds are pretty much locked in at the top. And then it gets dicey.</p><p>Yes, Lockport won the most recent matchup with Homewood-Flossmoor. But H-F has beaten Lockport twice this season and owns signature wins over ranked teams in Loyola, Mount Carmel and Bolingbrook. As a result of those quality wins, the Vikings receive the top seed.</p><p>Marist and Lockport have similar records, but it’s Marist with the wins it can hang its hat on, beating Evanston, Centralia and Waukegan.</p><p>Brother Rice, Thornwood, Rich, Joliet West, Lincoln-Way Central and Bloom are all jockeying for the next six spots. There were plenty of head-to-head opportunities. But those still didn’t sort it out definitively.</p><p>Check out this mess: Thornwood beat Brother Rice; Brother Rice beat Joliet West; Rich beat Bloom; Thornwood and Rich have split; Bloom beat Thornwood, then Thornwood beat Bloom; Lincoln-Way Central beat Bloom; Thornwood beat Joliet West.</p><p>As a result, it goes to win totals, schedule strength and how a team is currently playing.</p><p>Bloom and Rich, despite how dangerous both could be in the regional as teams hovering around the .500 mark, simply have compiled too many losses. They drop as a result.</p><p>Brother Rice’s schedule has been daunting. They’ve played top 15 teams Neuqua Valley, St. Ignatius, Loyola, DePaul and Marist, and played them all tough with the exception of the DePaul loss. The Crusaders, who have beaten Joliet West, Oswego and St. Laurence, still sits with as many wins as any of these six teams in contention for the No. 4 seed.</p><p>Lincoln-Way Central has put together a solid season while quietly playing a competitive schedule with seven games against ranked teams. They’ve beaten both Bloom and Lockport, while playing Homewood-Flossmoor, Oswego East and Kankakee tough in losses.</p><p>The No. 6 seed comes down to what have you done for me lately?</p><p>After a hot 11-2 start, Thornwood is just 6-7 since. And it did beat Joliet West way back in November by a whopping 28 points. But it’s a different Joliet West team, one that would very likely be favored to beat Thornwood today in a rematch. Joliet West is 11-1 since Christmas with the lone loss to highly-ranked Bolingbrook in overtime.</p><p>And, finally, Rich has beaten Bloom twice.</p><h3>Fremd Sectional</h3><p>1. Fremd (22-2)<br>2. Palatine (23-4)<br>3. Hersey (17-6)<br>4. Stevenson (17-8)<br>5. Rolling Meadows (15-10)<br>6. Hoffman Estates (26-3)<br>7. Lake Zurich (12-13)<br>8. Schaumburg (17-10)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> The two rivals, Palatine and Fremd, are fighting for the top seed. They have split their two games. Palatine won 53-37 in the December matchup and Fremd won the most recent game, 65-63, in overtime.</p><p>Fremd has that recent win and the more high-profile wins outside of the Mid-Suburban League, including victories over Evanston, New Trier, Glenbrook North and York. That gets the Vikings the top seed in their own sectional.</p><p>Palatine slots in at No. 2, thanks to demolishing Stevenson and recently avenging its earlier loss to Hersey with a 50-37 victory in January.</p><p>Stevenson has been up and down. The Patriots own an impressive late January win over Waukegan, yet their seed has taken a hit of late. They’ve lost to both Lake Forest and Prospect, teams with a combined record of 20-30, along with losses to ranked teams Warren and York by a combined 55 points in the past week.</p><p>Rolling Meadows has established credibility in its 15-10 season with wins over Hersey, Riverside-Brookfield and Lyons while playing nine games this season against ranked teams, including one-possession losses to St. Patrick, Fremd and Palatine. The Mustangs deserve the No. 5 seed and could make an argument for a No. 4 seed.</p><p>By looking at just the won-loss totals, outsiders will believe Hoffman Estates deserves better. While the Hawks have certainly enjoyed a fun season with a glitzy record, it likely doesn’t warrant higher than a No. 6 seed.</p><p>Hoffman Estates played the No. 3 seed, Hersey, and lost by 26 points. And among the 26 wins, Hoffman Estates has beaten just five teams with a winning record, none of which is a 20-win team yet: Notre Dame, Sandburg, Vernon Hills, Schaumburg and Jones.</p><p>When you get past the top five or six seeds, the sectional nosedives quickly. But you have to take into consideration the schedule Lake Zurich has played in comparison to the teams still looking to be seeded in the top eight.</p><p>The Bears, who did beat Mount Carmel and Glenbrook North, have played 10 ranked teams this season and are going to be a dangerously low-seeded team here.</p><h3>Loyola Sectional</h3><p>1. DePaul Prep (22-3)<br>2. Evanston (22-5)<br>3. Loyola (21-6)<br>4. New Trier (21-7)<br>5. St. Patrick (21-4)<br>6. Lincoln Park (17-7)<br>7. Glenbrook North (19-8)<br>8. Niles North (20-7)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> DePaul moves up to Class 4A this year and embeds itself in a very strong sectional where six other teams have been ranked at some point this season. But the Rams have one loss all season to an in-state team: top-ranked Benet. DePaul is an obvious No. 1 seed.</p><p>Then there are four teams realistically jockeying for spots two through five. There is some head-to-head and schedule strength to sort this out as their win totals are all similar.</p><p>Evanston is playing well. There was the weekend blowout loss to highly-ranked Warren, but the Wildkits have won 12 of their last 14 games and have beaten New Trier and Loyola along the way. Coach Mike Ellis’ team should be the No. 2 seed.</p><p>Loyola beat New Trier. Even if that win came way back in November, it’s a decision-maker when you’re splitting hairs between the two.</p><p>New Trier is an enigma when it comes to the seeds, because four of its seven losses came with star player Christopher Kirkpatrick injured. The Trevians have now won seven of eight but Kirkpatrick is still out and his return remains in question.</p><p>St. Patrick had its chance to muck things up in this seeding process last week. But the loss to Loyola did them in when it comes to moving up the seeding ladder.</p><p>Plus, the Shamrocks, a third-place finisher in Class 3A last season who have moved up to 4A this year, are just 1-4 against ranked teams. Loyola, meanwhile, has gone 5-5 in facing 10 ranked teams and New Trier is 7-6 against teams that have been ranked this season.</p><p>That leaves Lincoln Park and the three Central Suburban League teams that have all squared off with each other.</p><p>Lincoln Park has played the toughest schedule of the four teams contending for the No. 6 seed. The Lions just picked up a rock solid win over Peoria Richwoods over the weekend, and they’ve played several others, including Bolingbrook, Young and Mount Carmel, very tough.</p><p>What to do with the three CSL teams, Maine East, Glenbrook North and Niles North, with nearly identical records?</p><p>Anyway you look at it here, they settle in at No. 7, No. 8 and No. 9 in this sectional. But none of the three have signature, difference-making wins to solidify the No. 7 seed.</p><p>Surprising Maine East has an argument for the No. 7 seed as it has something neither Glenbrook North or Niles North have: wins over both. But Maine East, which did also lose to Niles North early in the season, has played the softest schedule of the three and has suffered the worst losses. The Monday loss to Maine West didn’t help.</p><p>Several of Maine East’s losses have come to the likes of Maine West, Sandburg, Vernon Hills, Notre Dame and Prospect. Glenbrook North, meanwhile, has lost games to teams that are or were ranked at some point this season: Hersey, Fremd, Stevenson, New Trier and Evanston.</p><p>And if Niles North were able to pull off an upset Tuesday night over highly-ranked Fremd (22-2), you can justifiably flip Niles North and GBN.</p><h3>Bolingbrook Sectional</h3><p>1. Benet (26-1)<br>2. Neuqua Valley (26-1)<br>3. Bolingbrook (20-7)<br>4. Downers Grove South (20-5)<br>5. Oswego (19-8)<br>6. Naperville North (21-6)<br>7. Oswego East (17-9)<br>8. Waubonsie Valley (15-10)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> Can a sectional be top heavy while also having depth? Sure. This sectional provides both as the top three teams — Benet, Neuqua and Bolingbrook — have been highly-ranked all season and boast the best individual talent in the sectional. Then the next group of six or seven teams offers balanced depth.</p><p>Benet and Neuqua have sparkling records. But Benet is clearly deserving of the top seed with the schedule it has faced and the wins it has secured, beating Curie, DePaul, Loyola, St. Patrick, Warren and two quality out-of-state teams from St. Louis, Chaminade and DeSmet.</p><p>Neuqua Valley’s big win over Bolingbrook back in January secures the No. 2 seed.</p><p>While Bolingbrook, Downers Grove South and Naperville North all have similar records, don’t let those records confuse you. Neither Downers South or Naperville North have played anywhere near the schedule Bolingbrook has this season.</p><p>That brings us to the most important two seeds in the sectional: No. 4 and No. 5. These two teams should be able to battle it out for a regional title while avoiding the three highly-ranked teams until the sectional. And it really works out nicely when you examine things.</p><p>Downers Grove South is the hottest of the remaining teams, winning 11 straight, though the streak doesn’t exactly include ranked teams or heavy hitters among the wins. The Mustangs, though, deserve to slide into one of the two coveted seeds and, specifically, the No. 4 seed due to its win over Oswego in December.</p><p>Oswego is also playing very well. The Panthers were 5-5 following a loss to Downers Grove South. But since then they’ve gone 14-3. Plus, the January win over Naperville North proved to be the most important win of the season for the Panthers, netting them the fifth seed.</p><p>The other two contenders are Naperville North and Oswego East, a team that has by far played the toughest schedule among these five teams. But again, DGS has the win over Oswego and Oswego has wins in the second half of the season over both Naperville North and Oswego East.</p><p>This should all work itself out nicely. Look for a Downers South at Oswego regional championship game.</p><p>The 8-10 seeds are really just a toss-up among Yorkville, Plainfield East and Waubonsie Valley. They’re all stumbling a bit in the last week. Yorkville did beat Plainfield East. But among common opponents, Waubonsie Valley has fared slightly better.</p><p>They’ll all be battling for the unenviable task of squaring off with Benet or Neuqua for a regional title.</p><h3>Rockton Hononegah Sectional</h3><p>Sub-Sectional A<br>1. Warren (24-2)<br>2. Waukegan (19-7)<br>3. Libertyville (14-9)<br>4. McHenry (18-9)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> No drama here for seeding week.</p><p>Warren is the overwhelming No. 1 seed, while Waukegan has beaten Libertyville twice this season. These two should meet up for a third time in the sectional semifinals.</p><p>When it comes to McHenry and Libertyville, it’s Libertyville that’s clearly played the better schedule. Libertyville beat Stevenson, while McHenry lost to Stevenson 59-27.</p><p>Sub-Sectional B<br>1. Rockford Guilford (20-5)<br>2. Rockford Auburn (20-7)<br>3. Rockton Hononegah (22-5)<br>4. DeKalb (11-17)</p><p><b>Overview:</b> Rockford Guilford has beaten both Auburn and Hononegah twice and is the team that is lining up to play Warren in the sectional championship.</p><p>With a resounding win over Hononegah in January, Rockford Auburn nabs the second seed.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-b40000" name="html-embed-module-b40000"></a><iframe title="No Shot Clock, Ep. 201: Conference quick takes" allowtransparency="true" height="150" width="100%" style="border: none; min-width: min(100%, 430px);height:150px;" scrolling="no" data-name="pb-iframe-player" src="https://www.podbean.com/player-v2/?i=5patj-1a40c88-pb&from=pb6admin&share=1&download=1&rtl=0&fonts=Arial&skin=1&font-color=auto&logo_link=episode_page&btn-skin=c73a3a" loading="lazy"></iframe> </div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Joe Henricksen

entries.title: No Shot Clock high school basketball podcast: Conference quick takes
entries.summary: <p>Joe Henricksen and Michael O’Brien’s weekly breakdown of Illinois high school basketball.</p><p>This week's episode opens with Two Takes and then Mike and Joe run through about a dozen conferences, giving their thoughts on surprise teams and players and notable performances this season.</p><p><b>The podcast is on </b><a class="Link" href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/no-shot-clock/id947571011" target="_blank" ><b>Apple Podcasts</b></a><b> and </b><a class="Link" href="https://open.spotify.com/show/2pmeJqzZusnzjQy7lXfP3m?si=ILyseKvYTxqjcoYRo3tMuA" target="_blank" ><b>Spotify</b></a><b>, so please subscribe.</b></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-b40000" name="html-embed-module-b40000"></a><iframe title="No Shot Clock, Ep. 201: Conference quick takes" allowtransparency="true" height="150" width="100%" style="border: none; min-width: min(100%, 430px);height:150px;" scrolling="no" data-name="pb-iframe-player" src="https://www.podbean.com/player-v2/?i=5patj-1a40c88-pb&from=pb6admin&share=1&download=1&rtl=0&fonts=Arial&skin=1&font-color=auto&logo_link=episode_page&btn-skin=c73a3a" loading="lazy"></iframe> </div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Michael O'Brien

entries.title: Entering college basketball's stretch run, here are 10 things to get you all caught up
entries.summary: <p>Congratulations on making it through <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >another football season</a>.</p><p>You came. You saw. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/06/seahawks-patriots-super-bowl-60-bad-bunny-or-the-commercials-heres-how-you-voted" target="_blank" >You made your thoughts known on Bad Bunny</a>, and thank goodness for that. Where would the world be without your approval of, or harrumphing over, a Super Bowl halftime performance? Thank you for your service.</p><p>Football is <i>finito</i>, the Winter Olympics are somersaulting by like a 115-pound snowboarder and baseball is still rubbing the sleep out of its eyes. This — right here, right now — is when you dive into the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/college-sports" target="_blank" >college basketball</a> season if you’ve yet to do so. Selection Sunday is barely a month away.</p><p>To those who keep college hoops at arm’s length until all the footballs are back in the equipment closet, this 10-item catch-up on the men’s season is for you.</p><p><b>1. No. 1 Arizona and the Big 12: </b>The Wildcats were 23-0 and unanimously first in AP voting before losing a nailbiter Monday at Kansas. Houston and Iowa State both are in the top five, and the Jayhawks solidly in the top 10. This is the top-ranked conference according to all the metrics, as strong — or stronger — toward the top as it was Baylor and Kansas won back-to-back national titles in 2021 and 2022.</p><p><b>2. No. 2 Michigan and the Big Ten: </b>Arizona has nothing on the 22-1 Wolverines, who lead all power-conference teams in scoring margin, and the Big Ten still could end up proving itself to be the best league. Nebraska, Illinois and Michigan State all are in the top 10, with old standby Purdue knocking on the door.</p><p>“I think there’s five legit chances to get to the Final Four,” television analyst Bruce Weber, who coached in the Big Ten and the Big 12, said of Illinois and its conference peers.</p><p><b>3. The Skyin’ Illini: </b>The tallest team in the country has had even more height on the floor while 6-2 guard Kylan Boswell has been out with a broken hand, but Boswell’s eventual return will make a Final Four-caliber team even better, especially at the defensive end. The breakout of freshman Keaton Wagler has been dizzyingly impressive. The Illini are an NCAA 2 seed according to current bracketology, with a real chance to finish strong and move up to a 1. Circle Michigan at Illinois on Feb. 27 on your calendars in fat marker right now.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center><div class="Enhancement-item"> <div class="ExternalContent-wrapper" data-embed> <iframe width="200" height="113" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/IOXQgB2hEFE?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="Illinois' Keaton Wagler ERRUPTS for 46 Points with NINE 3's In Upset Win Over Purdue! 🤯 EVERY POINT"></iframe> </div> </div></div><p><b>4. Best Big Ten tournament ever: </b>At the very least, it’s certain to be a compelling West Side story from March 10-15 at the United Center. On the other hand, there’s a high chance of an all-too-classic screwing of the champion by the NCAA selection committee, whose members will be sipping umbrella drinks with their feet up by the time the final buzzer goes off on Sunday.</p><p><b>5. Sweet and Elite: </b>The Midwest regional semis and final will be at the UC this year. It’s looking a lot like Michigan as the Midwest No. 1 seed, but Illinois still has time to roar through the next month and steal that sucker. Either way, Sweet 16 and Elite Eight games here will hit the spot.</p><p><b>6. Woe, Cats: </b>Anyone else old enough to remember Northwestern’s back-to-back NCAA Tournament appearances way back in 2023 and 2024? What a fall-off since then for the Wildcats, who went 7-13 in the Big Ten last season and are a miserable 2-11 this season. At least the next two games — against Michigan and Nebraska — should be nice and easy, right?</p><p><b>7. City living: </b>DePaul has kept a lot of Big East games close, but there it is tied at the bottom of the standings anyway. Loyola is in last place in the Atlantic 10 — what has happened to the Ramblers? — and UIC is hanging in there in the top half of the Missouri Valley. Not a whole lot to see here, all in all.</p><p><b>8. This, that and the other: </b>Miami (Ohio) is the last unbeaten left, at 24-0. It turns out having the 313th-toughest schedule, according to KenPom, makes things a little easier. Who knew? … Loyola has Saint Louis coming in next, and the Billikens are 11-0 in the A-10 and on a 17-game winning streak. Coach Josh Schertz to the Big Ten this offseason? … Defending national champ Florida is quietly — very quietly — in first place in the SEC, which is having a down season. Just don’t forget about the Gators.</p><p><b>9. National player of the year: </b>Duke’s Cameron Boozer — son of ex-Bull Carlos — has it in the bag. He’s having a better freshman campaign than last year’s top dog, Duke’s Cooper Flagg, had.</p><p><b>10. National coach of the year: </b>Michigan’s Dusty May? Arizona’s Tommy Floyd? How about Nebraska’s Fred Hoiberg? They’re all in roughly equal contention, and several others — among them Illinois’ Brad Underwood — are still in the race.</p>
entries.author: Steve Greenberg

entries.title: Woman charged with multiple felonies after alleged Roseland stabbing
entries.summary: <p>A Chicago woman is scheduled to appear before a judge Tuesday, charged with multiple felonies after allegedly stabbing and seriously injuring another woman Saturday in Roseland on the Far South Side. </p><p>Doniece Bell, 25, was arrested in the 9200 block of South Burnside Avenue roughly 30 minutes after the stabbing and charged with attempted murder, aggravated battery and burglary, Chicago police said.</p><p>The stabbing, which took place just before 10 p.m. Saturday in the 300 block of East 95th Street, left a 34-year-old woman seriously injured, police said. </p><p>Bell was scheduled to appear in court for a detention hearing Tuesday. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Art Institute of Chicago hangs Norman Rockwell painting of the Cubs
entries.summary: <p>In what will likely be a major draw for the museum, the Art Institute of Chicago on Tuesday installed its first-ever Norman Rockwell painting, and it depicts the Chicago Cubs.</p><p>“The Dugout,” Rockwell’s 1948 artwork, ran as a cover of the “Saturday Evening Post.” The work shows dejected Chicago Cubs players whose faces hang long after losing a doubleheader against the Boston Braves. Behind them, Braves fans appear to howl with delight, reveling in their team’s victory.</p><div class="Enhancement FormEnhancement" data-align-center> <div id="Form-newsletter-wrapper" class="Form-newsletter-text-wrapper"> <div class="Form-newsletter-title"> Green Room Newsletter </div> <div class="Form-newsletter-submissionSuccess"> <p><b>You’re subscribed!</b></p><p></p><p>Please check your inbox for your confirmation.</p> </div> <div class="Form-newsletter-description">Stay ahead of what’s hitting Chicago stages, galleries, museums and more with Green Room, WBEZ’s weekly arts & culture newsletter!</div> <div class="Form-newsletter-errorMessage"><p>Sorry, there was an error registering your email.</p></div> </div> <form data-ajax-endpoint="https://sfmc-subscribe.wbez.org/v1/subscription" class="Form-newsletter-form" method="POST" > <div class="Form-newsletter-item"> <div class="EmailInput"><label class="EmailInput-label"><span>Email</span> <input class="EmailInput-input" type="email" name="email" placeholder="name@email.com" required aria-required="true"> </label> </div> <button class="Button" type="submit">Sign Up </button> </div> <div class="Form-items-item"> <input type="hidden" name="acquisition_campaign" value="ARTS_Affordance"> </div> <div class="Form-newsletter-disclaimer"> <p>By subscribing, you agree with WBEZ’s <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/terms-of-use" target="_blank" >Terms of Use</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/privacy-policy" target="_blank" >Privacy Policy</a></p> </div> </form> </bsp-form> </div> </div><p>The historic piece is a gift to the Downtown museum from former Illinois Gov. Bruce Rauner and his wife, Diana. According to an online listing from the auction house Christie's, “The Dugout” last sold in 2009 for $662,500. The company estimates its present-day value between $700,000 and $1 million. Other Rockwell works have fetched as much as <a class="Link" href="https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2013/12/04/248790682/norman-rockwells-saying-grace-sells-for-46-million-at-auction" target="_blank" ><u>$46 million</u></a>.</p><p>On Tuesday morning, the iconic slice of American art history with special hometown ties took its place among the Art Institute’s sprawling collections.</p><p>Inside a gallery in the American art wing, curator Sarah Kelly Oehler welcomed two handlers who wheeled in the painting on a cart, each of them wearing Cubs baseball hats and surgical gloves as they carefully hung the work on the wall. Looking on were the Rauners and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/art/2026/01/29/art-institute-chicago-president-james-rondeau" target="_blank" ><u>James Rondeau,</u></a> the museum’s president and director. Rondeau called the painting a “truly transformative acquisition.”</p><p>The former governor said the work is his favorite painting, but as he approaches his 70th birthday, he said it felt like the right time to make the gift. This is the Rauners’ first donation to the museum, other than being members for a “gazillion years,” Diana Rauner joked.</p><p>“We enjoyed the painting for a very long time, just in our home, and in our family,” Diana Rauner said. “But it's really a painting for our community, and so we wanted to share it with the Chicago community.”</p><p>Rockwell’s “Dugout” now resides directly across from another legendary work, Grant Wood’s “American Gothic,” which is an Art Institute highlight. Oehler hopes the Rockwell piece, which is on view to the public starting Wednesday, will also become a popular destination for museum visitors.</p><p>“We will have two icons standing shoulder to shoulder, looking at one another, because they're so thematically appropriate to be together,” Oehler said. “What is more American than baseball? And certainly our own Chicago Cubs, so it just seemed like the absolutely perfect place to put it.”</p><p>Although it was a magazine cover commission, this realistic work is an early draft — or “study” — when Rockwell was working out the details. And unlike the final product, this version measures more than three feet, both in length and height.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6a4a152/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1394x782+0+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fac%2F1e%2F16f2b17a4e2a852cf05f1dc1d5f1%2F20260210-aicnewart-rgb.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Norman Rockwell. <i>The Dugout</i>, 1948. Gift of The Honorable Bruce V. Rauner and Diana M. Rauner. <i>Dugout</i> illustration © SEPS licensed by Curtis Licensing. All rights reserved.</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-3e0000" name="module-3e0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Norman Rockwell’s “The Dugout” depicts five people who participated in a 1948 baseball game between the Chicago Cubs and the Boston Braves. From left: Cubs rookie pitcher <b>Bob Rush (1)</b>; Cubs manager and former first baseman <b>Charlie Grimm (2)</b>; Cubs catcher <b>Rube Walker (3)</b>; Braves batboy <b>Frank McNulty (4)</b>, posing in a Cubs uniform; and Cubs pitcher <b>Johnny Schmitz (5)</b>.</div> </div><p>Oehler said the Art Institute has been in conversation with the Rauners about the piece for the last 10 months and officially received the gift in late December. On average, the museum <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/museums/2026/01/09/chicago-art-institute-acquisitions-richard-hunt-sculpture-christian-schad-amanda-williams" target="_blank" ><u>adds about 1,000 works</u></a> to its already-massive collection annually. For Oehler, this is a standout.</p><p>“I've long identified a Norman Rockwell as being something that we would want in the collection,” said Oehler, who oversees the museum’s American art collection and is the vice president of curatorial strategy. “I never dreamed, I will admit, that it would be this particular Norman Rockwell that it would be such a perfect Chicago painting.”</p><p>Despite being immortalized by Rockwell, the 1948 Cubs were not a stellar baseball team. In fact, their lousy record is what intrigued the artist. In May of that year, Rockwell convinced some good-natured players to model for him.</p><p>Ultimately, the work shows rookie pitcher Bob Rush; Cubs manager Charlie Grimm, who had also played for the Cubs as a first baseman; catcher Rube Walker, whose hat is pulled down over his eyes; and All-Star pitcher Johnny Schmitz with a furrowed brow. In the foreground, a batboy with a raised eyebrow steals the scene. In reality, the batboy, Frank McNulty, worked for the Braves, but after Rockwell offered him $5, he agreed to model in a Cubs jersey, according to Oehler.</p><p>Rockwell also recruited spectators to sit above the dugout and make faces of both delight and disappointment, according to an <a class="Link" href="https://www.saturdayeveningpost.com/2018/10/rockwell-files-the-1948-chicago-cubs-in-boston/" target="_blank" ><u>article published online</u></a> for the cover’s 70th anniversary in 2018.</p><p>The artist captured his models in a series of photographs. Then, according to Oehler, Rockwell used the photos to draft several iterations of the cover before it ran in September. First, Rockwell sketched in black-and-white graphite, then created the detailed oil painting that’s now at the Art Institute.</p><p>“It's very painterly. It has this beautiful sense of light and color,” Oehler said. “There's this wonderful green glow to it that is quite different from the actual cover. So it's really him working as a painter to try out these ideas and play with contrast and tonalities in the composition.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-ae0000" name="image-ae0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/cc9a187/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F20%2F5aa64eec4751a53fb75e4a4b0c84%2Faicnewart-260211-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/d585964/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F20%2F5aa64eec4751a53fb75e4a4b0c84%2Faicnewart-260211-1.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5961ce8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F20%2F5aa64eec4751a53fb75e4a4b0c84%2Faicnewart-260211-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Tim Roby (left), department specialist of the Arts of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago, and Chris Shepherd, senior specialist of the Arts of the Americas, roll in a “The Dugout” by Norman Rockwell, a new addition to the wing, at the Art Institute of Chicago in the Loop, Tuesday, Feb. 10, 2026." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5961ce8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F20%2F5aa64eec4751a53fb75e4a4b0c84%2Faicnewart-260211-1.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/8178955/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F20%2F5aa64eec4751a53fb75e4a4b0c84%2Faicnewart-260211-1.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5961ce8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe6%2F20%2F5aa64eec4751a53fb75e4a4b0c84%2Faicnewart-260211-1.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Tim Roby (left), department specialist of the Arts of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago, and Chris Shepherd, senior specialist of the Arts of the Americas, roll in a “The Dugout” by Norman Rockwell.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Rockwell was born in 1894 in New York and became one of the most famous artists working in the 20th century. His detailed depictions of everyday life mostly entered Americans’ homes through his famous magazine covers.</p><p>Rockwell is perhaps most closely associated with the Saturday Evening Post. Over a nearly five-decade run, Rockwell produced <a class="Link" href="https://www.saturdayeveningpost.com/history-saturday-evening-post/" target="_blank" ><u>322 covers for the publication</u></a>, which at its peak in 1960 boasted a circulation of nearly seven million — driven, in part, by Rockwell himself.</p><p>Despite widespread popularity, his longstanding relationship with the magazine is also what sometimes gives Rockwell’s work a reputation of being exclusionary. These illustrations almost always depicted white Americans, including what is perhaps Rockwell’s most famous work, “Freedom of Speech,” in which a man stands in dissent at a local town meeting.</p><p>However, later in his career, Rockwell famously drew scenes from the Civil Rights Movement, including “The Problem We All Live With,” which depicts a young Black girl accompanied by U.S. Marshals as she encounters overt racism on her way to school. The work for Look magazine was inspired by Ruby Bridges, who in 1960 became the first Black student to integrate her formerly all-white school in Louisiana.</p><p>“I think what Rockwell really did was capture a sense of the United States throughout a long and turbulent history,” Oehler said. “While sports were clearly so central to his practice and to his work, he also did works about much more difficult subjects.”</p><p>Last fall, some of <a class="Link" href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/voices/2025/11/02/norman-rockwell-trump-dhs-anti-immigrant-social-media/86949410007/" target="_blank" ><u>Rockwell’s descendants</u></a> rebuked the Trump administration’s use of his artwork on social media to, as they wrote for USA Today, persecute immigrant communities and people of color.</p><p>“We — as his eldest son, grandchildren and great-grandchildren — believe that now is the time to follow in his footsteps and stand for the values he truly wished to share with us and all Americans: compassion, inclusiveness and justice for all,” the family wrote.</p><p><i>Courtney Kueppers is an arts and culture reporter at WBEZ. </i><br></p>
entries.author: Courtney Kueppers | WBEZ

entries.title: Chicago police officer involved in Dexter Reed shooting accused of threatening detective at NW Side bar
entries.summary: <p>One of the Chicago police officers who fatally shot Dexter Reed during a traffic stop in 2024 has now been accused of threatening to beat up a fellow cop at a Norwood Park bar over the weekend.</p><p>Thomas Spanos, who fired 34 rounds and reloaded his weapon during <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/dexter-reed" >the deadly gunfight with Reed</a>, approached a group of men early Saturday at Tommy’s on Higgins and tried to pick a fight, according to a police report. Spanos was flanked by another officer, Nicholas Prozanski, and two other people.</p><p>Police said the threats stemmed from a “previous incident” at the bar about a week earlier, and the detective who was accosted was listed as the victim in the report.</p><p>“I’m going to beat your a--,” the “offenders” were quoted as saying in the report. “Let’s go I will fight you. I know where you and your family live.”</p><p>When both groups exited the bar, 6954 W. Higgins Ave., Spanos, Prozanski and the two others “started jumping up and down as if they were wanting to fight,” the report states. The detective then called 911.</p><p>The police department’s Bureau of Internal Affairs and the city’s Civilian Office of Police Accountability have opened investigations into the allegations. Spanos and Prozanski remain on active duty, a police spokesperson said. </p><p>An attorney for Spanos said he hadn't been informed of the new allegations. Spanos and Prozanski couldn't immediately be reached.</p><p>Spanos was one of four officers who <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/dexter-reed" target="_blank" >opened fire</a> when Reed shot another cop in the hand during a traffic stop in Humboldt Park in March 2024. Spanos and three other members of the Harrison District tactical team <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/police-reform/2024/04/09/dexter-reed-fired-first-chicago-police-officers-100-shots-copa" target="_blank" >fired a total of 96 shots at Reed</a> in less than a minute — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/police-reform/dexter-reed-shooting/2024/04/25/dexter-reed-shot-13-times-deadly-gunfight-police-autopsy" target="_blank" >striking him 13 times</a> and leaving him dead.</p><p>Spanos was the last officer to stop shooting, firing at Reed six seconds after he’d exited his SUV and fallen to the ground, according to a report by the Cook County state’s attorney’s office. State’s Attorney Eileen O’Neill Burke <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/dexter-reed/2025/08/13/chicago-police-shooting-dexter-reed-traffic-stop-murder-crime-eileen-oneill-burke-cook-county" target="_blank" >ultimately declined to file criminal charges</a> against the officers, finding they were in reasonable fear for their lives.</p><p>Reed’s family <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/police-reform/dexter-reed-shooting/2024/04/24/family-dexter-reed-federal-civil-rights-lawsuit-killing-chicago-police" target="_blank" >filed a federal civil rights lawsuit</a> against the city, alleging officers unlawfully pulled over his SUV and were “outrageously” aggressive as they approached him. The City Council’s Finance Committee <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/police-reform/dexter-reed-shooting/2025/04/11/dexter-reed-settlement-rejected-city-council-finance-committee-chicago-police" target="_blank" >rejected a deal to settle the case</a> for $1.25 million last year.</p><p>COPA’s investigation into the shooting has been closed, but the findings haven't been released.</p><p>The agency has found that Spanos and other officers who pulled over Reed stopped and searched two other drivers without justification weeks before the fatal shooting. Police Supt. Larry Snelling agreed with COPA’s recommendation that Spanos receive up to a 30-day suspension in each case. The oversight agency recommended the same level of discipline when investigators found Spanos was previously involved in another improper stop a year earlier.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/police-reform/dexter-reed-shooting/2024/05/28/dexter-reed-shooting-chicago-police-officers-stripped-powers-active-duty" target="_blank" >Chicago police oversight chief questions why cops in Dexter Reed shooting still have police powers</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/police-reform/dexter-reed-shooting/2024/05/28/dexter-reed-shooting-chicago-police-officers-stripped-powers-active-duty" target="_blank" >Before gunfight with Dexter Reed, Chicago cops made 50 traffic stops in just 3 days</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/dexter-reed/2025/08/13/chicago-police-shooting-dexter-reed-traffic-stop-murder-crime-eileen-oneill-burke-cook-county" target="_blank" >No charges for Chicago police officers involved in deadly shoot-out with Dexter Reed</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>

entries.title: Fuerza Regida, J Balvin y Kali Uchis encabezan el Festival Sueños 2026
entries.summary: <p>El Festival de Música Sueños regresa al Grant Park de Chicago los días 23 y 24 de mayo, con artistas destacados como Kali Uchis y J Balvin, que se unirán a Fuerza Regida, previamente anunciado.</p><p>Anunciado el martes, el programa también incluirá a Danny Ocean, Tokischa, Manuel Turizo y Yandel, quien ofrecerá “Sinfónico”, una presentación especial. Los DJs del festival, Fredy Fresco, Dynamiqo y Miriam Paz de Chicago, también vuelven.</p><p>Sueños se ha convertido en un evento tradicional durante el fin de semana del Día de los Caídos desde su lanzamiento en 2022, lo que marca el inicio de la temporada de festivales de música en la ciudad. Este año es uno de tres festivales anunciados para el fin de semana festivo.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-c10000" name="module-c10000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Sueños “se creó para ser un evento inclusivo, con la misión de seguir celebrando y elevando la cultura latina y la extraordinaria música, las personas, la comida y la increíble energía que la acompañan”, dijeron los organizadores del festival en un comunicado de prensa.</p><p>Esta es la segunda edición del Festival Sueños desde que los organizadores firmaron un acuerdo de cinco años con el Distrito de Parques de Chicago en julio de 2024 para producir el festival hasta 2029.</p><p>Durante los últimos cinco veranos, Sueños ha crecido hasta convertirse en uno de los festivales de música latina más destacados del país, atrayendo a más de 60,000 asistentes por día. El año pasado, los terrenos del festival se ampliaron con un segundo escenario para un festival más grande hasta ahora.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://suenosmusicfestival.com/passes/" target="_blank" >El pase de festival de dos días a partir de $329</a> saldrá a la venta el jueves a mediodía.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Morgan Ciocca | Vocalo

entries.title: Phil Ponce's message about the ICE blitz: 'None of us can do everything. But all of us can do something'
entries.summary: <p>Readers sometimes ask me what they can do.</p><p>They don't need to explain exactly what it is they want to do something about. You either know already or never will.</p><p>I take the question seriously. The news is both bad and good. On the bad side, there is not much any individual can do in a nation hurtling in a terrifying direction. We are all on the bus. None of us is driving. The cliff looms.</p><p>On the positive side, there is always something, and taking action seems necessary, to some of us. If only to tell ourselves, "I did something. I didn't just sit by and watch it happen." Pointing and shouting "The cliff!" might not stop the bus. But it could help.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-floatRight><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-e00000" name="module-e00000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Opinion bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Opinion</h2></div> </div><p>Those protesting the presence of ICE proved that regular people turning up on ordinary days to witness and record extraordinary abuses have an effect. The bus did seem to veer, maybe even slow. For now, anyway.</p><p>I tell people: Do what you can. You have skills; use those skills. I write stuff, much of which boils down to "The cliff!" It's my job. Others are prompted by some detail of the general national catastrophe. </p><p>For retired Chicago TV newsman Phil Ponce, it was seeing that the two Border Patrol agents suspected of killing Alex Pretti in Minneapolis are, like himself, Hispanic.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/01/28/va-nurse-vigil-alex-pretti-call-ice-border-patrol" >Hundreds honor Alex Pretti, call for abolition of ICE and Chicagoans to join nationwide general strike</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>"I expected to see someone directly addressing the Latino ICE agents," said Ponce, 76, former host of "Chicago Tonight." He decided to be that someone.</p><p>"I started thinking how Latino agents are interacting with their own community," he said. "What that might be like."</p><p>He saw an opportunity.</p><p>"I put in my mind the figure of somebody who believes in what he or she is doing as an ICE agent and thought, 'How could I meet them halfway, so I could have a conversation?'"</p><p>Ponce spent days writing a script.</p><p>"I agonized over it, trying to walk the line between being overly preachy and too sympathetic," he said. "I thought, 'How would I talk to my children if one of them were an ICE agent?' If I were talking to my own kid, I wouldn't yell at them. That'll not get you anywhere. That's not what a loving parent does. You have go respect someone, attempt to establish common ground."</p><p>This led to <a class="Link" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v46uNZ4HmWk" target="_blank" >“A Father’s Message to Ice,” </a>a 2-minute and 41-second video shot last week. I saw it on Facebook and encourage you to take a look.</p><p>He begins talking about himself:</p><p>"My name is Phil Ponce. My parents were born in Mexico — I was born in South Texas, McAllen."</p><p>Ponce tells the ICE agents he's addressing that he understands they're just trying to make a living and support their families.</p><p>"I get it, and I respect you for it," he says. "But at what cost?"</p><p>He points out that they're not arresting the worst of the worst, as claimed.</p><p>"Most of the people you are targeting are not criminals," Ponce says. "When you confront an immigrant, I've got to think you sometimes see the faces of your parents, your siblings, your grandparents. That's your conscience."</p><p>He turns the screws a bit — look at your fellow agents. What kind of people are they?</p><p>"How do you think they'd treat your family members if they encountered them on the street?"</p><p>Ponce ends with the softest veiled threat.</p><p>"Official records and unofficial recordings can last a lifetime," he muses. "You don't know what that could lead to down the road."</p><p>Translation: You could be sitting in prison someday for a split-second decision made outside a Home Depot.</p><p>But the thrust of the appeal is to shared culture and humanity, and the need for each person to live with themselves.</p><p>"I want you to be able to look your family and your people in the eye and be able to say you did your best."</p><p>He ends with a line in Spanish:</p><p><i>"Piénsalo con calma y cuídate."</i></p><p>Translation: Think about this calmly and take care of yourself.</p><p>Ponce hasn't heard from any ICE agents, yet. But then, the video hasn't been disseminated as widely as I hope it will be. Maybe sharing it could be your way of doing something.</p><p>If you watch the video, you may notice how professional it is — so polished, it almost looks like AI. Ponce called his friend Bill Kurtis, who sent a cameraman, lighting technician and a teleprompter from his production company.</p><p>"We all reacted to the shooting," said Kurtis, the retired Chicago news anchor. "You have to ask yourself: 'What kind of a country do you want? And what are you going to do about it?'"</p><p>"My motto is, none of us can do everything," Ponce said. "But all of us can do something."</p>
entries.author: Neil Steinberg

entries.title: Administración de Trump niega la apelación de ayuda de Illinois por los desastres de las tormentas de verano
entries.summary: <p>La administración de Trump ha negado oficialmente un recurso del estado de Illinois para fondos de asistencia por desastres causados por las tormentas del verano pasado que afectaron a 438,000 residentes en cinco condados de Illinois.</p><p>El gobernador JB Pritzker solicitó la autorización de la asistencia individual de la Agencia Federal para el Manejo de Emergencias (FEMA) para los condados afectados, así como programas de préstamos por desastres para ayudar a los habitantes de Illinois después de una tormenta de varios días del <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2025/08/20/residentes-del-lado-suroeste-frustrados-por-las-inundaciones-repetidas-esperan-que-la-alcaldia-los-ayude" target="_blank" >16 al 19 de agosto</a> que pasó por los condados de Boone, Cook, Kane, McHenry y Will.</p><p>Trump aprobó en octubre declaraciones de desastre mayor para Alaska, Nebraska, Dakota del Norte y la Banda Leech Lake de Ojibwe. Pero también <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/donald-trump/2025/10/24/dick-durbin-tammy-duckworth-donald-trump-denial-illinois-disaster-assistance" target="_blank" >negó solicitudes de Illinois</a>, Maryland y Vermont.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-e60000" name="module-e60000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Al anunciar asistencia para Alaska y Dakota del Norte, Trump publicó en las redes sociales que él ganó Alaska “EN GRANDE” en 2016, 2020 y 2024. Hizo lo mismo con Dakota del Norte.</p><p>Esto llevó a Pritzker a calificar la negativa como políticamente motivada y a intentar apelar la decisión. En dos cartas enviadas a Trump el año pasado, Pritzker dijo que la intensa lluvia abrumó el sistema de alcantarillado de Chicago en el lado suroeste, así como en Cicero y otros suburbios, afectando a muchos residentes “económicamente vulnerables”.</p><p>Los sobrevivientes de las inundaciones están lidiando con peligros para la salud, incluyendo moho y contaminación por las aguas residuales, condiciones que pueden causar problemas respiratorios en niños y adultos mayores, según las cartas.</p><p>En noviembre pasado, el Chicago Sun-Times detalló los daños por inundaciones de una residente de Garfield Ridge Park que hicieron que su sótano se llenara de aguas residuales. La madre soltera y sus tres hijos vivieron lo que docenas de miles de personas de la <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2025/08/06/chicago-cook-county-issue-disaster-proclamation-after-july-flooding" target="_blank" >ciudad y el Condado de Cook</a> soportaron durante las fuertes lluvias en julio y agosto, según documentos revisados por el Sun-Times que incluían la historia de la familia no nombrada, junto con ejemplos de muchas otras.</p><p>El dinero para desastres es proporcionado por FEMA, y el estado ha recibido históricamente cientos de millones de dólares tras condiciones climáticas severas.</p><p>Pero en una carta fechada el sábado, FEMA reafirmó su decisión inicial, escribiendo que no se justificaba la asistencia federal suplementaria. La negativa se aplicó específicamente a la solicitud del estado de asistencia individual para los residentes de los condados de Boone, Cook, Kane, McHenry y Will.</p><p>Pritzker calificó el lunes la negativa como “una decisión políticamente motivada que castiga a miles de familias de Illinois en un momento crítico de necesidad”.</p><p>“Jugar a la política con el financiamiento de la ayuda por desastres es un nuevo punto bajo, incluso para la administración de Trump”, destacó Pritzker en un comunicado. “Ignorar las realidades del daño generalizado causado por las tormentas severas de agosto de 2025, habla volúmenes sobre las prioridades vindicativas del gobierno federal y su completo desprecio por los medios de vida de los estadounidenses”.</p><p>La Casa Blanca ha defendido su decisión, diciendo que el presidente responde a las solicitudes de ayuda federal “con gran cuidado y consideración, asegurando que los dólares de los contribuyentes estadounidenses se utilicen de manera adecuada y eficiente por los estados para complementar, no sustituir, su obligación de responder y recuperarse de los desastres”.</p><p>“Llamemos a esto lo que es: una decisión políticamente motivada que castiga a miles de familias de Illinois en un momento crítico de necesidad. Jugar a la política con el financiamiento de la ayuda por desastres es un nuevo mínimo, incluso para la administración de Trump”, dijo el gobernador JB Pritzker. “Ignorar las realidades del daño generalizado causado por las tormentas severas de agosto de 2025, habla volúmenes sobre las prioridades vindictivas del gobierno federal y su completo desprecio por los medios de vida de los estadounidenses.”</p><p><i>Contribuyó: Brett Chase</i></p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Tina Sfondeles

entries.title: Trump administration cutting millions in Illinois HIV prevention grants, citing 'agency priorities'
entries.summary: <p>The Trump administration is planning to slash $600 million in public health grants for Illinois and three other Democrat-led states, including $5.2 million in cuts for an HIV prevention program at Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital.</p><p>In total, at least $29 million in Illinois grants are on the chopping block, including city, state and other health centers' HIV prevention programs, according to a list of grants obtained by the Chicago Sun-Times. The list represents a first wave of cuts, which is anticipated to total around $600 million, and it specifically targets family planning and HIV prevention programs. </p><p>The New York Times on Monday reported the pending cuts to programs in California, Colorado, Illinois and Minnesota. They also included $7.2 million in grant cuts to the American Medical Association in Illinois, which supports gender affirming care.</p><p>An HHS spokesperson confirmed the total amount of cuts, including the $5.2 million in cuts for Lurie grants. </p><p>"These grants are being terminated because they do not reflect agency priorities," a U.S. Department of Health & Human Services spokeperson told the Sun-Times on Tuesday. </p><p>Lurie was among several hospitals being referred by Trump administration officials for an investigation by the HHS office of inspector general last month, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/health/2026/01/20/lurie-childrens-pauses-gender-affirming-meds-under-18" target="_blank" >prompting them to further restrict gender-affirming care</a>.</p><p>According to a list of grants obtained by the Sun-Times, the cuts include a $441,625 grant to the Puerto Rican Cultural Center for its comprehensive HIV prevention program, $600,000 for the Illinois Department of Public Health's HIV prevention and surveillance program and $600,000 for the Chicago Department of Public Health's support and scale-up of HIV prevention in sexual health clinics — and $360,000 for its Sexually Transmitted Infection Surveillance Network. </p><p>Other cuts include $441,625 to the South Side Help Center's "comprehensive High-Impact HIV Prevention Project," $441,625 to Alliance Care 360's HIV prevention program and $383,599 for a University of Chicago program called "Experimental Evidence on the Effects of Academic Remediation on Violence."</p><p>There are several Illinois cuts linked to a program aimed at strengthening public health systems through national partnerships, including $6,299,354 earmarked to the Illinois Department of Public Health, $1,100,001 to the American Academy of Pediatrics, $4,116,000 to the American Medical Association of Illinois, $1,535,000 to the Health Research Educational Trust and $3,392,043 to the National Opinion Research Center. </p><p>Illinois grants that are being cut include the Illinois Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System, which received no money in the fiscal year that began in July, but $952,500 the prior year; $250,000 for Injury Prevention and Control Research program, and $930,841 for a medical monitoring project. </p><p>Gov. JB Pritzker's office said it had not been notified of any public health cuts, but called them an attempt "to politicize and punish certain states President Trump does not like."</p><p>"It’s wrong and often illegal, so Illinois will always fight for the resources and services our taxpayers are owed," a governor's office spokesperson said. "As with most news, we have not been notified as the Governor's Office receives information and communications from the White House through TruthSocial and media reports."</p><p>U.S. Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi criticized the cuts, saying it will "weaken hospitals, undermine disease tracking, and put lives at risk in the middle of real public health threats."</p><p>"This is politically motivated cruelty masquerading as policy, and I will fight to reverse it," Krishnamoorthi wrote on X. </p><p>As of Tuesday, Howard Brown Health said it was still assessing if the proposed funding cuts will trickle down to any of their existing programs. They noted that surveillance and HIV prevention has been key to reducing transmission of the virus.</p><p>“Over the past two years, the Chicago area has seen an increase in new HIV diagnoses, with a troubling number of individuals presenting with advanced disease at the time of diagnosis,” said Travis Gayles, chief executive officer of Howard Brown, in a statement. “This follows significant progress made during earlier Ending the Epidemic efforts under previous federal administrations, when expanded prevention, testing, and care initiatives led to measurable declines in new infections.</p><p>Lurie and the American Medical Association in Illinois did not immediately respond to a request for comment.</p>
